elements.content: The physical properties of materials are highly depend on their structural characteristics, especially the dimensions. Typical illustrations for such structure–property relationships have been well demonstrated by carbon materials. Distinct electronic, luminescent, conductive, and mechanical behaviors are generated from carbon quantum-dot or fullerene (zero dimensions, 0D), carbon nanotube (one dimension, 1D), graphene (two dimensions, 2D), and diamond (three dimensions, 3D). To help the rational design of functional materials, it still remains a great interest to construct such a complete structure–dimension system in other areas of materials.
elements.clean_text: The physical properties of materials are highly depend on their structural characteristics, especially the dimensions. Typical illustrations for such structure-property relationships have been well demonstrated by carbon materials. Distinct electronic, luminescent, conductive, and mechanical behaviors are generated from carbon quantum-dot or fullerene (zero dimensions, 0D), carbon nanotube (one dimension, 1D), graphene (two dimensions, 2D), and diamond (three dimensions, 3D). To help the rational design of functional materials, it still remains a great interest to construct such a complete structure-dimension system in other areas of materials.

elements.content: Titanium dioxide (TiO2) and related Ti–O nanomaterials have been widely applied as photocatalysts for light driven water splitting and environmental pollutants degradation. In the past decades, as the well-defined models of TiO2, crystalline titanium–oxo clusters with precise information on atomic positions have also attracted increasing research interest. From the structural dimensions perspective, the Ti–O clusters can be regarded as analogues of 0D carbon dots, while TiO2 belongs to a 3D framework connected by Ti and O atoms. Very recently, a Ti42–oxo cluster has been found to have symmetrical beauty similar to that of C60 fullerene. This finding promotes us to explore other multidimensional materials in Ti–O structures, which may bring novel physical properties to this important family.
elements.clean_text: Titanium dioxide (TiO2) and related Ti-O nanomaterials have been widely applied as photocatalysts for light driven water splitting and environmental pollutants degradation. In the past decades, as the well-defined models of TiO2, crystalline titanium-oxo clusters with precise information on atomic positions have also attracted increasing research interest. From the structural dimensions perspective, the Ti-O clusters can be regarded as analogues of 0D carbon dots, while TiO2 belongs to a 3D framework connected by Ti and O atoms. Very recently, a Ti42-oxo cluster has been found to have symmetrical beauty similar to that of C60 fullerene. This finding promotes us to explore other multidimensional materials in Ti-O structures, which may bring novel physical properties to this important family.

elements.content: In the course of our research on titanium–oxo clusters, we recently found that a robust [Ti6O4(OiPr)10(O3P-Phen)2]2+ {Ti6} (O3P-Phen = phenylphosphonic acid) cluster could be stably functionalized by different organic ligands to allow systemic bandgap adjustment. Herein we further apply it as a platform to study the assembly engineering of titanium–oxo clusters into multidimensional structures (). According to the soft and hard acid–base theory in coordination chemistry, Cu and Ti ions have affinities to nitrogen and oxygen, respectively. Thus, copper halides and bifunctional N/O-donor ligands are selected as inorganic and organic linkers for the assembly of titanium–oxo clusters. Finally, up to 17 titanium–oxo cluster based new materials have been prepared and characterized, whose molecular structures exist across the full dimensions from 0D nanoclusters to 1D chains, 2D layers, and 3D diamond frameworks (). During the assembly process, polynuclear transition metal doping has been achieved in the area of Ti–O materials for the first time, which endows the obtained compounds with colorful light absorption and various bandgap structures. Moreover, the developed assembly method has further been extended to the macroscopic material scale. A bimetallic Cu–Ti layer is successfully coated to a single Ti–O crystal through surface metal–nitrogen coordination bonds, resulting in interesting core–shell materials with defined atomic structure and distinct light absorption.
elements.clean_text: In the course of our research on titanium-oxo clusters, we recently found that a robust [Ti6O4(OiPr)10(O3P-Phen)2]2+ {Ti6} (O3P-Phen = phenylphosphonic acid) cluster could be stably functionalized by different organic ligands to allow systemic bandgap adjustment. Herein we further apply it as a platform to study the assembly engineering of titanium-oxo clusters into multidimensional structures (). According to the soft and hard acid-base theory in coordination chemistry, Cu and Ti ions have affinities to nitrogen and oxygen, respectively. Thus, copper halides and bifunctional N/O-donor ligands are selected as inorganic and organic linkers for the assembly of titanium-oxo clusters. Finally, up to 17 titanium-oxo cluster based new materials have been prepared and characterized, whose molecular structures exist across the full dimensions from 0D nanoclusters to 1D chains, 2D layers, and 3D diamond frameworks (). During the assembly process, polynuclear transition metal doping has been achieved in the area of Ti-O materials for the first time, which endows the obtained compounds with colorful light absorption and various bandgap structures. Moreover, the developed assembly method has further been extended to the macroscopic material scale. A bimetallic Cu-Ti layer is successfully coated to a single Ti-O crystal through surface metal-nitrogen coordination bonds, resulting in interesting core-shell materials with defined atomic structure and distinct light absorption.

elements.content:
Summary of the Overall Compositions, Structural Dimensions, and Bandgaps of the Reported Materials<xref ref-type="table-fn" rid="t1fn1"></xref> complex formula dimension bandgap (eV) PTC-3 [Ti6O4(OiPr)10(O3P-Phen)2(INA)2] 0D 3.69 PTC-20 [Ti6O4(OiPr)10(O3P-Phen)2(NA)2] 0D 3.76 PTC-21 [Ti6O4(OiPr)10(O3P-Phen)2(PS)2] 0D 3.69 PTC-22 [Ti6O4(OiPr)10(O3P-Phen)2(MPZ)2] 0D 3.71 PTC-23 [Ti6O4(OiPr)10(O3P-Phen)2][CuIICl2(NA)2] 1D 3.15 PTC-24 [Ti6O4(OiPr)10(O3P-Phen)2][CuIIBr2(NA)2] 1D 2.33 PTC-25 [Ti6O4(OiPr)10(O3P-Phen)2][CuI 2Cl2(NA)2(PPh3)2] 1D 2.65 PTC-26 [Ti6O4(OiPr)10(O3P-Phen)2][CuI 2Br2(NA)2(PPh3)2] 1D 2.62 PTC-27 [Ti6O4(OiPr)10(O3P-Phen)2][CuI 2I2(NA)2(PPh3)2] 1D 2.56 PTC-28 [Ti6O4(OiPr)10(O3P-Phen)2][CuICl(INA)2] 2D 2.11 PTC-29 [Ti6O4(OiPr)10(O3P-Phen)2][CuIBr(INA)2] 2D 2.29 PTC-30 [Ti6O4(OiPr)10(O3P-Phen)2][CuII(INA)2] 2D 2.27 PTC-31 [Ti6O4(OiPr)10(O3P-Phen)2][CuIICl2(PS)2] 2D 3.14 PTC-32 [Ti6O4(OiPr)10(O3P-Phen)2][CuI 2Br2(PS)2] 2D 2.87 PTC-33 [Ti6O4(OiPr)10(O3P-Phen)2]2 [CuI 4Br4(NA)4] 3D 2.89 PTC-34 [Ti6O4(OiPr)10(O3P-Phen)2]2[CuI 4I4(NA)4] 3D 2.61 PTC-35 [Ti6O4(OiPr)10(O3P-Phen)2]2[CuI 4I4(MPZ)4] 3D 2.45 PTC-36 [Ti6O4(OiPr)10(O3P-Phen)2]3[CuI 4I4(NA)3(DABCO)]2 3D 2.68

O3P-Phen = phenylphosphinic acid; INA = isonicotinic acid; NA = nicotinic acid; PS = pyridine-3-sulfonic acid; MPZ = 2-pyrazine-carboxylic acid; DABCO = 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]­octane.

At first, four different N/O-donor ligands, including isonicotinic (INA), nicotinic (NA), pyridine-3-sulfonic (PS), and 2-pyrazine-carboxylic acid (MPZ), are introduced to the phosphonate-stabilized {Ti6} core giving rise to colorless compounds (PTC-3, PTC-20 to 22; PTC denotes polyoxo-titanium cluster). From the assembly point of view, these clusters can be considered as nanosized building blocks with pyridine functionalized surface. Interestingly, after adding copper halides (CuX) into the reaction systems, Cu-doped Ti–O complexes PTC-23 (X = Cl) and PTC-24 (X = Br) () were obtained. They can be viewed as one-dimensional (1D) chains made up of the {Ti6} clusters and mononuclear Cu dopants (Figure S22). Bond valence sum (BVS) analysis (Table S19) reveals the +2 valence state of the Cu center, which is in good agreement with their blue or green colors. Solid state diffuse reflectance spectra studies indicate that both PTC-23 and PTC-24 present two light absorption bands between 250 and 800 nm, with the boundary point at 460 nm for PTC-23 and 550 nm for PTC-24. According to the Kubelka–Munk function, the bandgaps of PTC-23 and PTC-24 are experimentally estimated to be 3.15 and 2.33 eV. Moreover, when triphenylphosphine (PPh3) molecules were further introduced, rhomboid {Cu2X2} units formed and served as two connected linkers to connect {Ti6} clusters into another three 1D linear chains, PTC-25 (X = Cl), PTC-26 (X = Br), and PTC-27 (X = I) (, , and Figure S33). The valence state of the Cu center in these materials has been confirmed to be +1, agreeing well with their yellow colors. Such reduction from Cu2+ to Cu+ has been previously observed. Interestingly, PTC-25, PTC-26, and PTC-27 present very intensive light absorption between 250 and 500 nm, making their bandgaps around 2.60 eV (, ). Therefore, compared to the 0D PTC-20, the bandgaps of these 1D chain complexes have been lowered by 0.54 to 1.36 eV.
elements.clean_text: At first, four different N/O-donor ligands, including isonicotinic (INA), nicotinic (NA), pyridine-3-sulfonic (PS), and 2-pyrazine-carboxylic acid (MPZ), are introduced to the phosphonate-stabilized {Ti6} core giving rise to colorless compounds (PTC-3, PTC-20 to 22; PTC denotes polyoxo-titanium cluster). From the assembly point of view, these clusters can be considered as nanosized building blocks with pyridine functionalized surface. Interestingly, after adding copper halides (CuX) into the reaction systems, Cu-doped Ti-O complexes PTC-23 (X = Cl) and PTC-24 (X = Br) () were obtained. They can be viewed as one-dimensional (1D) chains made up of the {Ti6} clusters and mononuclear Cu dopants (Figure S22). Bond valence sum (BVS) analysis (Table S19) reveals the +2 valence state of the Cu center, which is in good agreement with their blue or green colors. Solid state diffuse reflectance spectra studies indicate that both PTC-23 and PTC-24 present two light absorption bands between 250 and 800 nm, with the boundary point at 460 nm for PTC-23 and 550 nm for PTC-24. According to the Kubelka-Munk function, the bandgaps of PTC-23 and PTC-24 are experimentally estimated to be 3.15 and 2.33 eV. Moreover, when triphenylphosphine (PPh3) molecules were further introduced, rhomboid {Cu2X2} units formed and served as two connected linkers to connect {Ti6} clusters into another three 1D linear chains, PTC-25 (X = Cl), PTC-26 (X = Br), and PTC-27 (X = I) (, , and Figure S33). The valence state of the Cu center in these materials has been confirmed to be +1, agreeing well with their yellow colors. Such reduction from Cu2+ to Cu+ has been previously observed. Interestingly, PTC-25, PTC-26, and PTC-27 present very intensive light absorption between 250 and 500 nm, making their bandgaps around 2.60 eV (, ). Therefore, compared to the 0D PTC-20, the bandgaps of these 1D chain complexes have been lowered by 0.54 to 1.36 eV.

elements.content: Representation of the precise doping of copper halides in Ti–O materials with 1D, 2D, and 3D structures. (a) Dinuclear {Cu2Cl2} doped 1D Ti–O material (PTC-25) with precise structure. (b) Dinuclear {Cu2Cl4} doped 2D material (PTC-31) with precise structure. (c) Tetranuclear {Cu4Br4} doped 3D material (PTC-33) with precise structure. (d) Twofold tetranuclear {Cu4I4-DABCO-Cu4I4} doped 3D material (PTC-36) with precise structure. Color Codes: green, Ti; orange, Cl; brown, Br; pink, I; black, C; red, O; blue, N.
elements.clean_text: 1  Representation of the precise doping of copper halides in Ti-O materials with 1D, 2D, and 3D structures. (a) Dinuclear {Cu2Cl2} doped 1D Ti-O material (PTC-25) with precise structure. (b) Dinuclear {Cu2Cl4} doped 2D material (PTC-31) with precise structure. (c) Tetranuclear {Cu4Br4} doped 3D material (PTC-33) with precise structure. (d) Twofold tetranuclear {Cu4I4-DABCO-Cu4I4} doped 3D material (PTC-36) with precise structure. Color Codes: green, Ti; orange, Cl; brown, Br; pink, I; black, C; red, O; blue, N.

elements.content: Photophysical properties of the obtained materials. (a) Crystal photos of all complexes with various colors. (b) Solid-state absorption spectra of representative samples calculated by the Kubelka–Munk function.
elements.clean_text: 2  Photophysical properties of the obtained materials. (a) Crystal photos of all complexes with various colors. (b) Solid-state absorption spectra of representative samples calculated by the Kubelka-Munk function.

elements.content: On the basis of the structures of PTC-25 to 27, we can easily see that if the terminal PPh3 ligand could be replaced by another pyridine functionalized {Ti6} cluster, higher dimensional Ti–O materials would be achieved. Such an idea was then successfully realized by the introduction of the Ti6–(INA)2 unit from PTC-3, giving rise to 2D networks with the neutral Cu2X2 rhomboid dimers serving as four connected nodes (X = Cl, Br, I for PTC-28, 29, 30) (, Figure S49). In comparison to the 1D {Cu2X2}-{Ti6} chains, the absorption edges of these 2D {Cu2X2}-{Ti6} networks present about 100 nm redshift (from ∼500 to ∼600 nm). When Ti6–(PS)2 from PTC-21 was applied as linker, a similar 2D structure PTC-31 ( and Figure S65) could also been constructed. More interestingly, larger tetranuclear Cu4Br4 dopants were successfully built in the presence of PS ligand and CuBr2. And the Cu4Br4 tetramers function as tetrahedral linkers to connect the {Ti6} clusters into a unique bilayer structure of PTC-32 (Figure S71).
elements.clean_text: On the basis of the structures of PTC-25 to 27, we can easily see that if the terminal PPh3 ligand could be replaced by another pyridine functionalized {Ti6} cluster, higher dimensional Ti-O materials would be achieved. Such an idea was then successfully realized by the introduction of the Ti6-(INA)2 unit from PTC-3, giving rise to 2D networks with the neutral Cu2X2 rhomboid dimers serving as four connected nodes (X = Cl, Br, I for PTC-28, 29, 30) (, Figure S49). In comparison to the 1D {Cu2X2}-{Ti6} chains, the absorption edges of these 2D {Cu2X2}-{Ti6} networks present about 100 nm redshift (from ~500 to ~600 nm). When Ti6-(PS)2 from PTC-21 was applied as linker, a similar 2D structure PTC-31 ( and Figure S65) could also been constructed. More interestingly, larger tetranuclear Cu4Br4 dopants were successfully built in the presence of PS ligand and CuBr2. And the Cu4Br4 tetramers function as tetrahedral linkers to connect the {Ti6} clusters into a unique bilayer structure of PTC-32 (Figure S71).

elements.content: From a topological point of view, tetrahedral nodes are ideal for the construction of framework structures. Therefore, the above Cu4Br4 tetramers should have the potential to extend the {Ti6} clusters into 3D arrangements. Indeed, when the assembly temperature was increased, a 3D zeotype structure of PTC-33 consisting of Cu4Br4 tetramers and Ti6–(NA)2 linkers was successfully obtained ( and Figure S77). Isostructural PTC-34 could also be built when Cu4Br4 was replaced by Cu4I4. And further replacement of Ti6–(NA)2 by Ti6–(MPZ)2 gave rise to another isostructural PTC-35. Moreover, when 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]­octane (DABCO) was introduced to the synthetic reaction of PTC-34, two of the previous Cu4I4 clusters were bridged together by DABCO to form a 6-connected {Cu4I4-DABCO-Cu4I4} node, which then assembled the Ti6–(NA)2 clusters into 3D framework structure PTC-36 (d, Figure S93). All these successes illustrate the universality of the assembly strategy. By simplifying the Cu–X clusters as 4-connecting nodes, the structures of these 3D frameworks can be assigned to diamond topology. The bandgaps of these compounds are in the moderate values between 2.45 and 2.89 eV. However, the absorption spectra studies indicate that they all present obvious light absorption beyond their absorption edges (even after the measurement limit of 800 nm). Therefore, such 3D polymetallic doping has proven to be efficient for increasing the solar energy absorption.
elements.clean_text: From a topological point of view, tetrahedral nodes are ideal for the construction of framework structures. Therefore, the above Cu4Br4 tetramers should have the potential to extend the {Ti6} clusters into 3D arrangements. Indeed, when the assembly temperature was increased, a 3D zeotype structure of PTC-33 consisting of Cu4Br4 tetramers and Ti6-(NA)2 linkers was successfully obtained ( and Figure S77). Isostructural PTC-34 could also be built when Cu4Br4 was replaced by Cu4I4. And further replacement of Ti6-(NA)2 by Ti6-(MPZ)2 gave rise to another isostructural PTC-35. Moreover, when 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane (DABCO) was introduced to the synthetic reaction of PTC-34, two of the previous Cu4I4 clusters were bridged together by DABCO to form a 6-connected {Cu4I4-DABCO-Cu4I4} node, which then assembled the Ti6-(NA)2 clusters into 3D framework structure PTC-36 (d, Figure S93). All these successes illustrate the universality of the assembly strategy. By simplifying the Cu-X clusters as 4-connecting nodes, the structures of these 3D frameworks can be assigned to diamond topology. The bandgaps of these compounds are in the moderate values between 2.45 and 2.89 eV. However, the absorption spectra studies indicate that they all present obvious light absorption beyond their absorption edges (even after the measurement limit of 800 nm). Therefore, such 3D polymetallic doping has proven to be efficient for increasing the solar energy absorption.

elements.content: Up to now, we have successfully assembled the 0D {Ti6} clusters into 1D, 2D, and 3D materials with various copper halide dopants ranging from mononuclear and dinuclear to tetranuclear and twofold tetranuclear clusters. The Cu–N coordination bonds between copper halides and {Ti6} clusters play key roles for the success of the above hybrid construction. Meanwhile, they also promote us to further study the macroscopic assembly between different crystalline compounds to give rise to heteronanostructures with important applications in materials. Considering the structure characteristics of [Ti6O4(OiPr)10(O3P-Phen)2(INA)2] in PTC-3, it would be rational to assume that there are numerous pyridine groups pointing to the surface of the colorless crystals of PTC-3. Then if copper halides were further introduced, they could be possibly attached to the surface of PTC-3 through the former applied Cu–N coordination bonds. Following this consideration, CuCl was added into the postsynthetic reaction liquid of PTC-3 crystals and heated for another 4 days. Interestingly, core–shell crystals were obtained with colorless core and red shell (). The composition of this core–shell material has been investigated by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) and energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) analysis (Figure S101). Moreover, the crystalline states of the core and shell even allow the respective single crystal X-ray diffraction studies on them, further confirming the presences of the PTC-3 core and PTC-28 shell. Similarly, PTC-3@PTC-15 (Co-incorporated 1D ladder-type structure, see a right) core–shell structure has also been constructed, proving the general applicability of this method.
elements.clean_text: Up to now, we have successfully assembled the 0D {Ti6} clusters into 1D, 2D, and 3D materials with various copper halide dopants ranging from mononuclear and dinuclear to tetranuclear and twofold tetranuclear clusters. The Cu-N coordination bonds between copper halides and {Ti6} clusters play key roles for the success of the above hybrid construction. Meanwhile, they also promote us to further study the macroscopic assembly between different crystalline compounds to give rise to heteronanostructures with important applications in materials. Considering the structure characteristics of [Ti6O4(OiPr)10(O3P-Phen)2(INA)2] in PTC-3, it would be rational to assume that there are numerous pyridine groups pointing to the surface of the colorless crystals of PTC-3. Then if copper halides were further introduced, they could be possibly attached to the surface of PTC-3 through the former applied Cu-N coordination bonds. Following this consideration, CuCl was added into the postsynthetic reaction liquid of PTC-3 crystals and heated for another 4 days. Interestingly, core-shell crystals were obtained with colorless core and red shell (). The composition of this core-shell material has been investigated by powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) and energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) analysis (Figure S101). Moreover, the crystalline states of the core and shell even allow the respective single crystal X-ray diffraction studies on them, further confirming the presences of the PTC-3 core and PTC-28 shell. Similarly, PTC-3@PTC-15 (Co-incorporated 1D ladder-type structure, see a right) core-shell structure has also been constructed, proving the general applicability of this method.

elements.content: Macroscopic assembly of titanium–oxo cluster based heteromaterials. (a) Diagram of the coating of PTC-3 by Cu-doped PTC-28 and Co-doped PTC-15. (b) Photographs of the original PTC-3 crystal and the obtained core–shell composites.
elements.clean_text: 3  Macroscopic assembly of titanium-oxo cluster based heteromaterials. (a) Diagram of the coating of PTC-3 by Cu-doped PTC-28 and Co-doped PTC-15. (b) Photographs of the original PTC-3 crystal and the obtained core-shell composites.

elements.content: In summary, we have systematically studied the precise assembly engineering of titanium–oxo cluster based materials with copper halide dopants. On the basis of the different coordination affinities of Cu and Ti ions, {Ti6} clusters have been linked to a variety of polynuclear copper halides, including {Cu2X2}, {Cu4X4}, and {Cu4X4-DABCO-Cu4X4}, resulting in 1D chain, 2D layer, and 3D diamond framework materials. The successfully established polymetallic and multidimensional doping influence the light absorption and bandgap structures of polyoxotitanium clusters in a wide range. Moreover, such a coordination chemistry based molecular assembly method has further been applied to the construction of macroscopic core–shell crystals, whose core and shell structures are atomically defined. Therefore, our work not only provides new polymetallic and framework doping models for titanium oxide materials but also opens a new direction for the construction of molecular component based core–shell materials.
elements.clean_text: In summary, we have systematically studied the precise assembly engineering of titanium-oxo cluster based materials with copper halide dopants. On the basis of the different coordination affinities of Cu and Ti ions, {Ti6} clusters have been linked to a variety of polynuclear copper halides, including {Cu2X2}, {Cu4X4}, and {Cu4X4-DABCO-Cu4X4}, resulting in 1D chain, 2D layer, and 3D diamond framework materials. The successfully established polymetallic and multidimensional doping influence the light absorption and bandgap structures of polyoxotitanium clusters in a wide range. Moreover, such a coordination chemistry based molecular assembly method has further been applied to the construction of macroscopic core-shell crystals, whose core and shell structures are atomically defined. Therefore, our work not only provides new polymetallic and framework doping models for titanium oxide materials but also opens a new direction for the construction of molecular component based core-shell materials.

cln_elements.content:
<fig fig-type="scheme" id="sch1" position="float">
<label>1</label>
<caption>
<title>Illustration of the Precise Assembly of 0D Ti–Oxo
Clusters
To Give Rise to 1D (left), 2D (central), and 3D (right) Materials</title>
</caption>
<graphic id="gr1" position="float" xlink:href="cm-2017-00324w_0004.tif"></graphic>
</fig>
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Illustration of the Precise Assembly of 0D Ti-Oxo Clusters To Give Rise to 1D (left), 2D (central), and 3D (right) Materials

cln_elements.content: Representation of the precise doping of copper halides in Ti–O materials with 1D, 2D, and 3D structures. (a) Dinuclear {Cu2Cl2} doped 1D Ti–O material (PTC-25) with precise structure. (b) Dinuclear {Cu2Cl4} doped 2D material (PTC-31) with precise structure. (c) Tetranuclear {Cu4Br4} doped 3D material (PTC-33) with precise structure. (d) Twofold tetranuclear {Cu4I4-DABCO-Cu4I4} doped 3D material (PTC-36) with precise structure. Color Codes: green, Ti; orange, Cl; brown, Br; pink, I; black, C; red, O; blue, N.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Representation of the precise doping of copper halides in Ti-O materials with 1D, 2D, and 3D structures. (a) Dinuclear {Cu2Cl2} doped 1D Ti-O material (PTC-25) with precise structure. (b) Dinuclear {Cu2Cl4} doped 2D material (PTC-31) with precise structure. (c) Tetranuclear {Cu4Br4} doped 3D material (PTC-33) with precise structure. (d) Twofold tetranuclear {Cu4I4-DABCO-Cu4I4} doped 3D material (PTC-36) with precise structure. Color Codes: green, Ti; orange, Cl; brown, Br; pink, I; black, C; red, O; blue, N.

cln_elements.content: Photophysical properties of the obtained materials. (a) Crystal photos of all complexes with various colors. (b) Solid-state absorption spectra of representative samples calculated by the Kubelka–Munk function.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  Photophysical properties of the obtained materials. (a) Crystal photos of all complexes with various colors. (b) Solid-state absorption spectra of representative samples calculated by the Kubelka-Munk function.

cln_elements.content: Macroscopic assembly of titanium–oxo cluster based heteromaterials. (a) Diagram of the coating of PTC-3 by Cu-doped PTC-28 and Co-doped PTC-15. (b) Photographs of the original PTC-3 crystal and the obtained core–shell composites.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  Macroscopic assembly of titanium-oxo cluster based heteromaterials. (a) Diagram of the coating of PTC-3 by Cu-doped PTC-28 and Co-doped PTC-15. (b) Photographs of the original PTC-3 crystal and the obtained core-shell composites.

metadata.title:
Titanium–Oxo Cluster Based Precise Assembly
for Multidimensional Materials
